awd_titl_txt: GeoHazard: Modeling Natural Hazards and Assessing Risks
awd_abstract_narration:
As human populations grow and spread into areas where extreme natural events impact lives, there is increasing need for innovative Earth science curriculum materials that help students interpret data and and understand the factors and risks associated with natural hazards. Studying the processes underlying these naturally occurring events and the relationships between humans and their environments would enrich the standard Earth science curriculum by providing students with valuable insights about the potential impacts of extreme natural events. This project will respond to that need by developing and testing a new instructional approach that integrates a data analysis tool with Earth systems models in a suite of online curriculum modules for middle and high school Earth science students. Each module will be designed as a sequence of activities lasting approximately 7-10 class periods. These will be stand-alone modules so each teacher can implement just one module or several modules. The modules will facilitate development of rich conceptual understandings related to the system science of natural hazards and their impacts.  Students will develop scientific arguments that include risk assessment based on their understanding of real-world data and the particular Earth system being studied. The project will develop a set of computational models designed specifically to explore geoscience systems responsible for natural hazards. An open-source data analysis tool will also be modified for students to create and analyze visualizations of the magnitude, frequency, and distribution of real-world hazards and the impact of those hazards on people. Students will compare data generated from the Earth systems models with real-world data in order to develop an understanding of the cause and progression of natural hazards, as well as to make predictions and evaluate future risks. The Discovery Research preK-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects. 

The four-year, early stage design and development project will be conducted in two phases. In Phase 1, design-based research will be used to iteratively design and test Earth systems models. A team of five lead teachers will field test modules and provide focus group feedback during the development phase of the curricula. These lead teachers will provide input into the design and development of the tools, the organization and structure of the curriculum, and provide suggestions about classroom implementation to support the development of teacher support materials. After the models are developed, four curriculum modules related to hurricanes, earthquakes, floods, and wildfires will be developed, tested, and revised. In Phase 2, a group of 30 teachers will participate in implementation studies that will test usability of the modules across students from diverse backgrounds and feasibility of implementation across a range of classroom settings.  Research will focus on understanding how to support student analysis of real-world datasets in order to improve their conceptual understanding of complex Earth systems associated with natural hazards.  The project will also examine the role of uncertainty when students make scientific arguments that include predictions about the behaviors of complex systems and the uncertainties related to risk assessment.  The project aims to clarify student views of uncertainty and how teachers can better support student understanding of the inherently uncertain nature of systems, models, and natural hazards, while understanding that models can be used to reduce impact.  Questions guiding project research include: (1) How do students use flexible data visualizations to make sense of data and build and refine conceptual models about natural hazards?  (2) How do students incorporate data from models and the real world in formulating scientific arguments; how do students use scientific uncertainty to assess risks based on their understanding of a natural hazard system; and how do students quantify and explain risks to humans and compare different sources of risks? And (3) Do GeoHazard curriculum modules help students make gains in risk-infused scientific argumentation practice and conceptual understanding underlying natural hazards? To what extent, for whom, and under what conditions is the GeoHazard curriculum useful in developing risk-infused scientific argumentation practice and conceptual understanding?

por.por_cntn:
Understanding natural hazards is among the most pressing challenges of our age. The effects of climate change have resulted in a shift in the frequency and severity of these hazards, which now affect larger populations of people across the globe. Natural hazards are the result of the interactions of many environmental factors. To understand natural hazards  students must learn both the science behind these complex systems as well as the risks and potentially devastating impacts to people, ecosystems, and infrastructure. 

The GeoHazard project designed, developed, and tested three online curriculum modules focused on natural hazards common to different regions of the United States: hurricanes, wildfires, and inland flooding. Each module contains computational simulation-based investigations as well as real-world data about these hazards. As students move through the activities in each module, they are scaffolded in developing scientific arguments around potential risk and uncertainty. This holistic approach allows students to simulate a wide variety of possible scenarios and engage in authentic scientific practices, exploring the limitations and uncertainties of the models as they compare outcomes to real-world case studies. 

The project also developed three computational models. By conducting experiments with the Hurricane Explorer, Wildfire Explorer, and Flood Explorer models, students investigate the effects of a wide array of variables in each environmental system. Using evidence from their explorations, students reason about the effects of environmental factors on the hazard's formation, progression, and severity. The Hurricane Explorer allows students to investigate how the location and magnitude of pressure systems can determine a hurricane's path, as well as how sea surface temperature can affect a hurricane's strength. Students can also visualize the effects of storm surge under different hurricane conditions. The Wildfire Explorer models wildfire spread under different conditions such as wind speed and direction, terrain, drought level, and fuel type. Students also investigate the effects of fire suppression in the past on wildfires today. The Flood Explorer allows students to visualize the extent of flooding caused by different intensities of rain storms and experiment with surface permeability and flood mitigation techniques. Each model also contains variable settings for students to investigate how the risk and impact of hazards may change in the future in light of climate change. 

To measure students' science content knowledge about the specific natural hazard as well as their reasoning about risks, impacts, and mitigation strategies, the project developed research instruments for each module. Students significantly improved from pre- to post-test after using all three modules. A study specific to the hurricane module identified students' reasoning patterns in terms of different types of uncertainty when carrying out evidence-based science practices that include modeling and interpreting data with various representations. Findings in this study indicate that students are capable of articulating epistemic uncertainty related to knowledge and process. A study specific to the wildfire module found that students who conducted systematic experiments with the Wildfire Explorer scored significantly higher on post-tests. In addition, this study found that students of teachers who engaged in class discussions around the scientific concepts in the module as well as students' own personal experiences with wildfires had the highest pre- to post-test gains. Finally, research on the flood module showed that students who used the Flood Explorer to conduct controlled experiments with the simulation and observe important simulation outputs were more likely to develop risk assessment and risk mitigation strategies than those who did not. 

Each module comes with a suite of teacher support materials. First, a comprehensive Teacher Edition allows teachers to preview the curriculum that their students will use, access background science content, review pedagogical strategies for teaching with simulations, view exemplar student answers, and read suggested discussion points to use during class time. Second, pre- and post-assessments are available and also contain Teacher Editions. Third, support materials around teaching risks and impacts as well as discussing socio-scientific ideas in the classroom are provided. Finally, each module includes a real-time class dashboard that teachers can use to track their students' progress. 

The module and full suite of support materials are available on the Concord Consortium's STEM Resource Finder at:

https://learn.concord.org/geo-hurricane

https://learn.concord.org/geo-wildfire

https://learn.concord.org/geo-flood

Research publications are available on the project website:

https://concord.org/geohazard
